summary: Laryngeal cancer is a type of cancer that develops in any part of the larynx (voice box). It is typically a squamous-cell carcinoma. The prognosis is affected by the location of the tumour, which is divided into three anatomical regions: the glottis, the supraglottis, and the subglottis. Laryngeal cancer can spread by direct extension, metastasis to regional lymph nodes, or via the bloodstream.
causes: Combined use of alcohol and tobacco
Occupational exposure to certain chemicals in metalworking, petroleum, plastics, and textile industries
Infections by some forms of HPV
risk_factors: History of head and neck cancer
Chronic exposure to carcinogenic effects of alcohol and tobacco
symptoms: A sore throat that does not go away
Feeling that something is stuck in the throat
Pain or ringing in the ears
diagnosis: Imaging tests (chest x-ray, CT or MRI scans)
Biopsy (histological proof of cancer type and grade)
Examination of the larynx, trachea, and esophagus
Palpation of the neck and supraclavicular fossa for cervical adenopathy
Examination of the oral cavity and oropharynx
treatments: Surgery (partial or full removal of the tumour)
